title: Safety and Your Vehicle: Keep It Roadworthy
summary: Master the essential checks and legal duties that keep your vehicle safe, efficient, and DVSA-test ready.

sections.title: Why Vehicle Safety Matters
sections.body: A well-maintained car keeps you and everyone around you safe. Knowing your checks prevents breakdowns, fines, and serious incidents.

sections.title: DVSA Essentials
items: Use the POWDER (or POWERS) routine: Petrol, Oil, Water, Damage, Electrics, Rubber/Self.
Tyres must have 1.6 mm tread across the central three-quarters and be inflated to handbook pressures.
Seat belts and child restraints must be correctly fitted; it’s the driver’s legal responsibility (Rules 99–102).

sections.title: Pre-Journey Checks
items: Walk around the car looking for damage, leaks, or obstructions.
Check oil, coolant, brake fluid, and screenwash levels before long journeys.
Confirm lights, indicators, horn, wipers, and washers operate correctly.

sections.title: Dashboard Warnings Explained
sections.body: Red lights mean stop as soon as it’s safe. Amber lights need attention soon—book diagnostics or check the manual. Blue or green lights simply confirm systems are active, like full beam or cruise control.

sections.title: Keeping Occupants Safe
items: Adjust head restraints to eye level and close to the back of the head.
Stow loose items in the boot or secure storage to prevent injury in a collision.
Never place a rear-facing child seat in front of an active airbag.

checklist.label: I complete POWDER checks before lessons or long trips.
I know the correct tyre pressures and tread requirements.
I can identify key dashboard warning lights and the action to take.
I use and fit seat belts and child restraints correctly every time.

practiceTips.label: Weekly walkaround
practiceTips.detail: Set a reminder each Sunday evening to complete a five-minute inspection. Note anything to discuss with your instructor.

practiceTips.label: Know your manual
practiceTips.detail: Flag three dashboard symbols you’re unsure about and look them up tonight. Understanding them reduces stress on the road.

practiceTips.label: Theo’s Show Me/Tell Me hack
practiceTips.detail: Practise Show Me/Tell Me answers aloud while you carry out the physical check. Linking the words and action boosts memory.

questions.prompt: What’s the legal minimum tread depth for car tyres in the UK?

options.label: 1.0 mm across the entire tyre
options.explanation: This is below the legal requirement and unsafe in the wet.

options.label: 1.6 mm across the central three-quarters
options.explanation: This is the DVSA and legal minimum—check regularly with a gauge.

options.label: 2.5 mm across the whole tyre
options.explanation: 2.5 mm is recommended for best performance but not the legal minimum.

options.label: 3.5 mm on the outside edges
options.explanation: The law specifies 1.6 mm across the central three-quarters—not just the edges.

questions.prompt: A red oil pressure warning light appears while driving. What should you do?

options.label: Ignore it until the next service
options.explanation: Driving with low oil pressure can cause severe engine damage.

options.label: Stop as soon as it’s safe and check the oil level
options.explanation: Red warnings require immediate action to protect the engine.

options.label: Continue driving but reduce speed
options.explanation: Continuing risks a breakdown and costly repairs.

options.label: Switch on your hazard lights and carry on
options.explanation: Warning lights indicate a fault—you must stop and investigate, not keep driving.

questions.prompt: Which of these is part of the POWDER check?

options.label: Reviewing the sat-nav route
options.explanation: Sat-nav planning is useful but not part of POWDER.

options.label: Checking coolant and screenwash levels
options.explanation: Water includes coolant and washer fluid—both vital for safety.

options.label: Vacuuming the interior
options.explanation: Interior cleaning isn’t required for the safety check.

options.label: Checking the playlist for your journey
options.explanation: POWDER focuses on mechanical and safety checks, not entertainment.

questions.prompt: What’s the safest way to transport loose items like sports gear?

options.label: Leave them on the back seat for quick access
options.explanation: Loose items can become dangerous projectiles in a collision.

options.label: Store them in the boot or secure them with straps
options.explanation: Securing items protects you and your passengers during sudden stops.

options.label: Hold them on your lap while driving
options.explanation: Holding items distracts and compromises restraint systems.

options.label: Place them in the passenger footwell
options.explanation: Loose items in the footwell can roll under pedals and stop you braking properly.

questions.prompt: When should you check your tyre pressures for the most reliable reading?

options.label: When the tyres are cold, before a long journey
options.explanation: Cold tyres give the most accurate pressure reading—check before heat builds up.

options.label: Immediately after driving at motorway speeds
options.explanation: Heat from driving raises the pressure and gives a false reading.

options.label: After washing the car so the tyres are clean
options.explanation: Cleanliness doesn’t affect the gauge—temperature does.

options.label: Only during the annual MOT test
options.explanation: Tyre pressures must be checked regularly, not just once a year.
